commentBody: Caitlin may not have seen this trick before, but Jim Horne at xwordinfo.com has, and wrote: "Answers that turn corners in the grid is old hat by now, but 73-Across is superb justification." I enjoyed the revealer too, but I knew what to expect at the first themer from reading the puzzle title. I hope newcomers will have the same thrill I had the first time an answer turned a corner, and that old timers will have some appreciation for the execution here, even if the other shoe dropped years ago.

My first thought was IS THAT ALL THERE IS, until I realized that all seven phrases literally went downhill from HERE. Excellent!

And what a great debut of the revealer.

Nicely done, Rebecca and Michael.

I've always been confused by the revealer. I know what it means, but going downhill also means easy, or getting easier, and I've always wondered if it has two meanings/how others use it. If I use it, I usually mean getting easier from here, and nobody has ever corrected me.

The HERE trick lifted this puzzle from ordinary to spectacular.  That was one terrific   

BUTWAITTHERE
                           S
                           M
                            O
                            R
                             E

moment!
Argghhh! I had a typo somewhere, and it took me 10 minutes to find it! Other than that, nice puzzle.
This puzzle was joyful. There was no cutting corners!
Well, that was SOME puzzle!  I really enjoyed this one.  Happy Valentine's Day, everyone. <3
Maybe I’m foggy today but the was the most impenetrable crossword I’ve ever seen. Even without the theme of word drop-offs, 50% of the clues I had absolutely no idea. Not fun but that’s just me

For “middle of the night woe”, I originally had LEG CRAMP.  Then, reviewing the puzzle, I see so many other possible midnight woes that could disturb your sleep:

LOOSE ENDS
ARM RESTS
“I’M RUINED!”
ARSENIC
FAT CAT(s)
CONDOR (!)
SEDITION
“IS THAT ALL THERE IS?”
Just the right level of difficulty for a Sunday. Perfect!
Whatever happened to a straight-forward puzzle?
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2026/02/14/sunday-february-15-2026/#ny
Such a delightful puzzle! Impressively clever without (imo) being heavy handed. Bravo!

I turned all the corners on this one, but sometimes too soon, and had to back up, rethink, and RESPELL. For instance, what is "offinterest"?  Well, it isn't, but I seem to have an AFFINITY for blowing things up out of proportion and thinking I'M RUINED.  After I settled down, I was having a wonderful time when I entered IS THAT ALL THERE IS and suddenly it was over!

Michael and Rebecca it's still Valentine's Day where I'm solving, and I hope you're both having a stellar one.  It's our 42nd anniversary (56 years of being together), and the puzzle was perfect for a lazy afternoon (Hub was dozing).  Thank you!

This was a constructor’s tour de force, and enjoyable to solve as well. I figured it out once I got the revealer (and had a hunch before that) and it did make it a bit easier to be able to automatically add HERE at the end of the theme entries, but this was still an appropriately level of difficulty for a Sunday and deliciously fun to figure out. And again, this was no mean feat by two veteran solvers, a ton of theme material but all fresh and nothing too forced in both directions—and I loved the ending ISTHATALLTHEREIS because I certainly would have been ready for more.
A few other thoughts:
I had BUM for “rest area” at first and SEAT and REAR for “Bicycle setting”—I guess I got TUSHIE on the brain.
I couldn’t help but think of the recent UNDERCOVER BOSS puzzle when I saw NABOB and considered how appropriate CHI(NA BOB)SLED TEAM would have been for that puzzle during the Winter Olympics.
TIL Mar 10 is MARIO day, how fun!!!
Appreciated a lot of the fresher clues for the shorter entries today, like “It’s pressed for cash” and “Calls to task” and “in hot water”. Don’t know if they were original but seemed so to me.
Lastly two of my solving bugaboos today—ELASTIC or PLASTIC? WRIER or DRIER? And also WITS or BITE for sharpness?

Nice.  

Seemed a little bit obvious at Gaia. But overall was a very good puzzle.

Kicking myself. Missed the HERE, simply turned downhill at the end. As a result had ETHERiAL crossing DiAL (93A 89D) convincing myself that the latter had something to do with telephoning. DOH
Took a full fly speck to get it.
I was defeated at the corner of WEEDTEA and WRIER. I had "DRIER" and DEEDTEA, which I figured must be some brand of THC tea. Oh well.
Michael and Rebecca, what a pleasure. Thank you.
Enjoyable puzzle.  Found it easier than most Sunday puzzles, but still fun to complete. Once you realize how the theme of the puzzle translates to the answers, it’s pretty straightforward.

Oh, this was very enjoyable!! And I was even helped by figuring out the theme about halfway through. I was a bit slow getting the revealer, but loved the aha I felt when I got it! I was stoked to be able to put SEDITION back in. I'd taken it out when I filled in TEACHERS at 40A. I know the clue is singular, but I thought of it as TEACHER'S EDITION. I practically sprinted back there once I cracked the revealer. 

Kind of crazily, I confidently put CHEWOff at 10D, until I was happily forced to take it out. What the heck's a CHEWOff!? Is it like a hot dog eating contest, only you have to chew as many pieces of gum as you can without stopping? Hmm. I'd last about 30 seconds in that contest. Not a gum chewer am I! 

Extra fun one!!
41 minutes to solve, I got the idea with the MotherEarth clue.

Fun puzzle! This is why I subscribe and come back every day.

Always fun to have to figure out the trick, and then have the trick help with solving the toughest part of the grid (for me, the NW today).

This has been a good night.

First, I caught onto the trick very early.  I was uncharacteristically sharp when I saw that TEACHEREDITION turned a corner quite beautifully.  And I had it!

After that, I was filling things in quickly, all the while thinking this was going to another example of "too easy", and was feeling a little bad for those wizened solvers who are constantly on the lookout for a real challenge.  But it seemed to be ok with them, too.

But I didn't get the music when I first finished, and I spent probably ten full minutes looking for the error, with was the dRIER/dEEDTEA.  It felt like a little gift from the cosmos (in particular, from the Great Attractor which pulls thousands of galaxies in the Laniakea Supercluster) when I saw that W made everything even better.

W is a Wonderful letter.  As I learned from Sesame Street, without W a Waffle is just affle.  (More of a sound joke that a written joke, but everything here is way above average with wordplay.)

Cheers, everyone.  Off to make some WEEDTEA.

Very clever one today!  
When I suddenly figured out the trick, I
F
E
L
L out of my chair. **


** No puzzlers were harmed during the completion of the crossword.

Sweet puzzle.  Well crafted Sunday effort.  After first pass on the across clues, I was worried not finding anything confirming what I expected (wrongly) for a coffee (or beverage) topic in the themed clues.  But the down clues filled in nicely and quickly revealed the solution to the theme (seen it multiple times in past puzzles) - dead giveaway was the Gaia clue.  As always, a little patience prevails and resulted in 25% faster than average solve. Enjoy.
Got tripped up on BERT. For some reason, I never think of the Sesame Street gang as being Muppets.

BIG sigh of relief on 46A ["My life is over"]

At that point I had IMxUxxED.  My first guess was not IMRUINED.

For a minute I thought the NYT had completely become unravelled after yesterday's "screws" and "nails".
Is NABOB a mitsake?

I knew I was in for a treat when I saw the byline with two construction superstars.

I drank it up and it was GOOD TO THE LAST DROP!

What kind of wizardry was that that made all the themers drop after the word HERE? 

Astonishing construction chops. 
Bravo to both, Rebecca and Michael,
and thank you so much!
Except for 40A, oddly, I think all the theme answers are also all downhill from THERE.

Well, finally fed the emus... tried to say I had a short brain f at an apropos spot, but even though that's in the clue it didn't fly! I put "Soho" for the neighborhood, giving me "blasked". A perfectly lovely but so far meaningless word.
How are “EOE” fair-hiring initials?? (And shouldn’t it be “fair hiring” without the dash?) In any case, fair hiring initials are EEO.

userLocation: Spring Hill, just south of Armageddon
commentBody:
This puzzle was the bee's knees.

Brilliant theme execution and revealer.

Was I transported elsewhere through the multiverse of crucigrammatic space-time?  No.

Was I delighted?  Yes, I was.

I've come to be conscientious about reading the titles on Sunday puzzles, and this one was particularly useful, as I didn't hesitate to look beyond the ends of the themers for a drop finish. 24A was easy to pick up on, and 27A confirmed the trick, which was very nicely done. A few tricky spots for me, but still managed to finish this one well under my average time.

HERE's to the constructors! Thanks Rebecca and Mike! A very fun-to-do puzzle!

WRIER may be a word, but I don't think I've ever heard anybody say it or read it anywhere in my life!

I think I'd rather say: "This one is more wry than the other one!"

(By the way, Word Spell-check is now correcting me and not letting me say "more wry.")

What do you think?

I think Word Spell-check is changing our language in a lot of ways--by insisting on its way!

Also by the way, from the comments, I am getting the idea that a lot of people are uncomfortable with "wrier" and find it clumsy and unaccustomed to use. A lot of solvers got stumped at that answer.
My comment did not make it past the filter so please find it below the pic linked here: https://imgur.com/a/13Wjrpm

I've never watched "Sesame Street" and I know Bert only from memes known as Bert Strips: (Pearl clutchers beware: it's all inappropriate, dark humor without an emu filter) https://www.reddit.com/r/bertstrips/
2026 crossword hall of fame. Loved it.

Another Sunday recommendation from the archives, challenging but doable and the theme answers made me think and grin:

Sunday, March 26, 1995; "Positive Thinking" by Rich Norris

Breezy and so fun!

I had TUCHUS for TUSHIE for a while…

I had an unexpected advantage. My husband was watching the women’s Big Air Skiing competition at the Olympics while I solved. I’d look up occasionally and that’s definitely a case of everything being downhill from there.  And what a hill it is!

Once I grasped the trick, this went fairly quickly for a Sunday, and I mentally placed the puzzle in the "pleasantly clever" category. Then I read Caitlin's column and realized I had totally missed the HEREs that signal the starts of the downhill tumbles, at which point the puzzle went from clever to OMG! What an amazing feat of construction!
feeling very called out by 102A -- guess I was too excited to do the crossword to go back to sleep!
Very cool puzzle. I’m always impressed with how the constructors come up with such neat tricks. Well done!

Solved with two lookups:
 
33A [The moon’s “maria”]. I read the column, but I’m still not sure how I’m supposed to get to the answer from the clue. How do you know it’s Latin?

129A [Queen of the fairies]. I haven’t the faintest clue what this is from.

Incredibly clever. 
I got more clues today than ever before, over a very long time, but then I was held up by a few complete unknowns (sport, TV channel, initialisms) and some forgotten words - I must try to remember "sass".

I realised that there was 'something going on' but was too busy solving to really take it in. But that's fine, I'm here for the straightforward solve.

Well, the star of the puzzle, to me, is the word HERE.

I remember thinking, at some point during the fill-in, that this was simply a rehash of a crossword tricky-trope: the turn-down or turn-up of an answer.  It was well executed, but rather ordinary and disappointing, coming from the two pros that made this puzzle.  

Until HERE.  That changed everything. 

It changed the revealer from just signaling a downward turn to making it marvelously specific. It brought the amazement that comes when seeing something that was right in front of my eyes, but was blind to.  

Plus, my appreciation for the skill behind this build soared.  That HERE constricts so much -- the words that can come above and below it, and the number possible theme answers and dropping words. That on top of how those dropping words constrict the surrounding answers. Wow!

As cream, there was the marvelous SMITHEREENS!

Totally charmed by your puzzle, Rebecca and Michael. What pros you are.  I loved this. Thank you!

What a cracker. The sparkling fill, the amazing ability to develop a theme and clue system that has HERE in each appropriate place.
I got the trick with Gaia; knowing it had to be MOTHER EARTH, but how to fit it all in? The down crossing was the lightbulb moment. 
I raise my chapeau. Very well done indeed.

I know that we've gotten used to seeing clues and answers that might have been considered off color in previous years, but when I partially filled in 46A as IM_U__ED I was thinking "They wouldn't, would they?"

Then I found the credited response.

Fun puzzle. I misinterpreted my first get as TEACHER/SEDITION, which got me looking for answers that included the entire Down word, but then I got it, maybe when I saw how TWEENS fit in.

Even with 19A and 70A, no negativism here.

When *people* irresponsibly throw around words like 35D, I need a
HEADACHERE
M
E
D
Y

Or maybe just some 85D
This became a whole lot easier once I figured out the trick. At that point I could put “here” in in the appropriate place which made the down clue more apparent.
TEACHER EDITION confused me before I had the revealer because unlike all the other themers there's no THERE HERE.

Based on the constructors’ note, I’m guessing that when Mike pitched the theme idea to Rebecca, barely had he
BENTHERE
                  A
                  R
and immediately it
CAUGHTHERE
                       Y
                       E

When I finally spotted it, you could have knocked me over with a feather edge.

The first themer I filled in was MOTHER EARTH. But I wrote ARTH in the margin on my paper. Then got the revealer very quickly from a couple of crosses, so that let me know that all the theme answers would make a right turn downward. I then dutifully filled in the rest of the theme answers methodically, never realizing until I came here that the across parts all had the word HERE! That would have made it even quicker. Nice puzzle, though much easier than I expected from these two seasoned constructors.

HERE HERE!

Nice puzz.
Two thumbs up.

Now I'm having coconut cream pie 
for breakfast.

(In a good way.
Not the sad-morning-pie way.)

Didn't fully appreciate the theme until after finishing the puzzle, when I finally noticed that each of the seven thematic horizontal entries ends in HERE, as does the fitting revealer.

Was then disappointed that six of the seven themers actually ended in THERE, while the one that didn't (TEACHERE) yields the awkward TEACHER EDITION and not "teacher's edition". 

Liked a couple of the themers in which the downward portion was substantial, but, all in all, didn't find this one all that interesting. 

As I'm sure others will note (MOL, I'm counting on you!) DEAGED is a horrid "word".  Highlight for me is BEEN (clued with "It's ___ real") adjacent to ETHERE(AL). Can't wait to try out "It's been ethereal!" in some future conversation.

It is Teachers’ edition. 

“Teacher edition” is not a thing. 

Otherwise, I liked it.
Very enjoyable puzzle to start the week--well done and thank you!

Whew (again). Took me a good long time to tumble to the trick and I was really puzzled until that happened. Still a good long workout even after that. But... really clever piece of construction. 15 letter answer that dawned on me today was... NATTERINGNABOBS And.. that's been an answer in two puzzles. And... my puzzle find. A Sunday from January 31, 1999 by Manny Nosowsky with the title "Gaining weight." Some theme answers in that one: WALKTHEPLANKTON TRASHCANTON THEFAIRSEXTON CROWNPRINCETON STANDPATTON MINIATURECARTON Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/31/1999&g=113&d=A ....

Solid, fun. This must have been a nightmare to construct – great job you guys.
I have trouble with 63D. Gettin old and rickety, y'know.
Loved this one! Very satisfying and clever. I am in awe of the constructors' skills. Thank you!
Didn’t love “Next on my list” cluing to ABOUTTO.  Easy enough but didn’t feeeeeel right.  Same GL as FS?

Gah!  I missed it!!!!!  So glad I went to the blog first, before writing this.

Sure, I saw all the DOWNHILL answers.  They were already given away by the unfortunate title, GOOD TO THE LAST DROP, which unnecessarily makes an already easy puzzle even easier.  But I missed all the HEREs.  Even after seeing the wonderful revealer, I missed the pun.

Sometimes I feel I'm the most visually unobservant person who ever lived*.

The HEREs are what lift up this downward-headed puzzle and give it real shine.  It's a very clever revealer in a very well-executed puzzle.  It's quite easy -- a good Sunday puzzle to give to a novice solver, I'd say.  It will introduce them to both puzzle trickery and puzzle wordplay without discouraging them.  In their case, the giveaway title will be an added plus. As for me, I found this an entertaining puzzle to solve.

* Re visually unobservant:  One of those Nancy Guthrie crime scene videos in extreme closeup showed what some experts were calling perhaps a scar right under the wrist.

It's not that I said "What scar?".  I'm sure at least some of you did too.  It's that I said "What wrist?"

You don't ever want me as a witness to anything.  Not anything, ever.

Solved the revealer and understood the HERE endings. Thought the theme fell flat because I didn't even realize the downhill part until reading Wordplay. Gave me much more appreciation for the execution.

Timely theme as we watch recorded Olympics skiing!

Hooray for Breezy Johnson.

Enjoyed this challenging and smooth Sunday.

OoooooKAY.  First, it is my custom to Print on Two Pages so that I don't burn out my eyeballs, not to mention bypassing the need to use a magnifying glass to read the numerals in the Clues and on the Grid.  IF ONLY there was a kind of DEW Line, where on Saturday's puzzle one was warned that enlargement was not going to work, some people might not put in their eyeDROPs (speaking of DROP) which leave a body with blurry vision for quite some time.  

And it would be nice to have a more mysterious title on the puzzle, because this is something of An Old Trick--all too obvious, especially if one starts at the bottom of the puzzle with SASS and SEIS.  (I'm not trying to be UGLI here, but there's a headache behind my eyes, and I had plans to use these eyes when I switch out a foot on my sewing machine, which was designed by some engineer who doesn't use one.)

All that aside, how interesting to see a (nattering) NABOB, a GARNET, and ARSENIC (right after Valentine's Day? Tsk.)  
All y'all take care.  Don't get BLOWn TO SMITHEREENS!
I’m pleased to see the best player in the world, Nikola Jokić, in the NYT crossword!
I got ITSALLDOWNHILLFROMHERE early on, and, well, it was all downhill from there! Fun Sunday!

Never, in 10,000 eons or eras (get it? baseball, era) have I seen the A's referred to as ATH-letics. Not on scoreboards, not in box scores, not on tickers. I had LAS forever which was killer.

The amount of time it took me to cross Lids and Dams is just plain sad on my part. Clever clues.

Hererra, Harper, Bert was just sadistic.

But, a super fun puzzle. Thank you, creator. Cheers yall.
Titania McGrath
Great Sunday grid! Really enjoyed this.

Rebecca, Your puzzle was great, but, more importantly, we want to that you and your coworkers for your amazing work!  Our 30-something daughter is currently in treatment with one of your products and her cancer is responding dramatically.  Please share with your coworkers how absolutely grateful we are that you are saving her life.

The killer was the crossing of NOE with YEET. I never know contemporary slang, and this time cross clue failed me. Maybe I need to spend more time with my grandchildren.

It was a fun puzzle anyway.
I had never heard of the Grey Art Museum, but it sounds depressing.

"Next on my list" is everything I hate about vocalizations perfectly epitomized!  Even after solving, I don't get it.  Those are not the same things.  They just aren't.

Might as well just leave a giant question mark, it would actually be less confusing.

Technical nit: it would have been helpful if, when 73A was selected, the seven italicised clues had been highlighted (as things like this usually are).  Finding the italicized clues meant putting on the reading glasses.

But I loved this puzzle!  A perfect Sunday experience and the theme, once discovered, was a delightful aid to the sneaky 7.

Mic drop!

Now that was a Sunday puzzle, at least in my world. It was nice to spend over a half hour on one. I mean before the flyspecking part.

It does take awhile to flyspeck a grid this size. But until then it was a fun solve. Never stuck, but many pauses to think, a slow steady pace full of interest. Didn't get the trick until beginning my second pass through the Acrosses, and then really enjoyed it. But didn't notice the (right in your face!) HEREs until reading the column.

My flyspecking was due to misspelling ETHERiAL. I'd only been through the down clues once and should have left one square blank until I'd revisited those, but had already spent a satisfying amount of time on the grid and was feeling ready for a second cup of coffee.

Glad I didn't see the title before solving.
Lovely puzzle but a bit underwhelmed by 123A.
A chorus of HERE HERE for this construction.  Nicely done.

I was puzzled by today's photo atop the column, could not make out what they were doing.  So opened in a new tab and the title of the image revealed all: 

15wordplay-coffee-superJumbo.jpg

All right, slight nerd moment - I caught onto the theme immediately (for MOTHER EARTH) but that’s all thanks to Asimov.

Yes, _that_ Isaac Asimov, of the I, Robot fame. In addition to being a prolific author of science fiction he frequently ventured into other realms, such as a fascinating primer on the etymology of Greek words that came from myths.

While it is intended for kids, I would recommend *Words from the Myths* for all ages.

And while you’re at it, Asimov’s *Treasury of Humor* is also a must read. And who knows, it too could help with a crossword in the not-so-distant future ;-)

Funny that my brain fart today resulted in "blasked" because I initially put "Soho"... perfect place to get momentarily confused! 
On another note, enjoying what I hope is an intentional gathering of words like FATCAT, NABOB, SEDITION, and maybe even MARIO. Or it could just be my version of seeing a face in burned toast.
Don’t laugh but I thought sac fly was an insect. Clearly I don’t follow baseball hahaha. Fun one!!

So it *is* possible to have a Sunday grid with a theme other than a set of groaners. Nice. That was quite a cool trick. Or it could have been: the revealer was clued so directly it was an instant gimme and it pretty much spoiled the theme, giving it to me for free. Sigh.

As for the fill, this being Sunday I couldn't be arsed to deal with all of the trivia and flyspecking so I quickly checked the puzzle and did a few reveals. I have no regrets there.

Poland's most recent CENSUS was done during our latest illiberal, autocratic period (2015-2023), characterized by nationalism,  xenophobia, religiosity, disregard for science, corruption, nepotism, discrimination, and all the other stuff sadly known to modern Americans. It was a criminal offence to refuse to take part in the census, but I did all I could to show how I felt about it and its organizers - for example, in the field for nationality I chose "other" and wrote in "European": take that, anti-EU nationalists!

I left it alone overnight, but since nobody else has mentioned it: 
117D bothers me. 

ET AL isn't Latin, it's an abbreviation. There was no indication in the clue of it being a shortening. I think a fairer cluing would've been "Latin-derived list ender", or "Latin list ender, for short".

For the other quibblers in the crowd, a Latin list ender would be one of - et alii (masculine), et aliae (feminine), et alia (neuter), or et cetera.

On Tuesday, unless I get flattened by an early week puzzle, I should hit 2000. If I make it, I may post a bit about my solving saga next weekend. 

I'm not a purist and will (again) disclose my cheat rules.

Perfect Sunday puzzle IMHO, though I managed to miss the HERE component until I read Caitlin’s column (despite the obvious clue in the puzzle title). D’oh! For me, that clever trick elevated the construction such that I did something I rarely do once the gold star is in place—I went back to the puzzle just to look at it. 

Thank you, Rebecca and Mike!
First time I have solved the revealer before any of the theme answers, and knew immediately what it was telling us to do.
Incredible puzzle - very fun, required the right amount of effort, and a very enjoyable revealer. Top class!
The clue for 1A stands out as a recent favorite. And it was the last to fall for me today.
NE corner had me stumped. I woulda enjoyed the puzzle if it weren't for those clues.
113A. What a proud day for all of Fort Collins. We can now move on from balloon boy.

Didn’t like this puzzle or the theme. If the theme doesn’t make sense until you are nearly done then what is the point? 

The clueing is so bad that in a puzzle of this size it takes way too long to find the answers, plus there are plenty of made up phrases to fill the grid.

Okay - the most amazing puzzle I've ever encountered. A Tuesday from November 5, 1996 by Jeremiah Farrell. That was the day before the presidential election. Two seven letter crossing answers (39a and 43a) across the very middle of the puzzle separated by one black square. And... the clue for 39a was: "Lead story in tomorrow's newspaper (!), with 43 across." And the answer to 43 across was ELECTED. But the answer to 39 across could be either... CLINTON or BOBDOLE And both of those worked with crossing down answers. A couple of examples. 39 down: "Black Halloween animal" so... BAT or CAT 40 down: "French 101 word" so LUI or OUI Other down crossing alternatives... BRA or IRA OUI or LUI YARD or YARN BITS or BIOS BOAST or BLAST NRA or IRA Just amazing. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/5/1996 ...

Happy Sunday! Caught on to the theme with "smithereens". Time is moot, because I kept looking up at the Olympics.
Good day for a sports-watcher. Olympics, Pebble Beach, Daytona, and more. 
Have a good one.
Loved this puzzle, thank you
Great puzzle. It brought back the memory of the iconic Maxwell House red neon sign in Hoboken, which was very visible from downtown manhattan .
Don't get 13A. Anyone?

My lightbulb went off with teacher edition.  I thought it was gonna have a speed bump effect with the s in sedition. Making it teacher’s edition. But I came down with Mother Earth. Truly an enjoyable puzzle.
I enjoyed this one and I'm glad there aren't a lot of comments that it was too easy! 🤪 Maybe I'm starting to get the hang of these things.
NABOB?
Is WEEDTEA Good to the Last Drop? (Asking for a friend)
Yeah I don’t think personal bests mean much anymore so just solve it your way, whatever makes you feel right that day :)

What an elegant puzzle. I needed the column to tell me about the extra flourish of the “here” before the answers went down. I went back to look at the puzzled and marvelled at the ingenuity of it. That must have been so challenging to do!

Generally good clues here, especially for a Sunday.
I'm assuming for experienced folks this was fairly easy. There were a lot of things I've never heard of but got them all with crosses, which means the other clues were on the easy side. Muckety muck/ NABOB (googled afterwards).
EASTS I(rom the card game?) 
EOE (that acronym is not a thing over here, googled after)
ALBA was new.
ICEE I should have remembered from previous puzzles.
TRIB
NOHO
DDE
ERIE as a county
TOMTIT
NOE

Overall close again, but no cigar has been my pattern for the last few days. Today I couldn't parse out BLAsK__. I had sOHO for the New York district, never heard of NOHO, so I never considered SOHO could be wrong. My knowledge of US presidents is not what it might be and EER felt like it could be 15 different things instead of the first E. 30 minutes of messing around with it didn't help, BLANKED never occurred because that's not what I think a brain fart is.

Had the whole rest of the grid correct without getting the theme, just assumed the trick was that the end of some words were missing. My general blindness to themes continues.

Forgot to mention that I never thought I’d see an assistant coach make it to the crossword, but big shout out to Tex Winter, winner of 10 NBA titles and my mental toughness award for maintaining his sanity despite dealing with so many Everest sized egos for so long.

Plus the coaching genius thing of course.
Halfway through, 46-across is looking mighty suspicious. I'm pretty sure the crossword wouldn't allow the words that are forming in my mind.

I never post comments but had to today! 
Big achievement managing to spot the theme after I had got the main clue. LOVED IT. Usually I get the theme after a lot has been filled in but not today! 

Nearly completed the entire puzzle but did need a little help on the US specific questions (UK based!)

What a clever, satisfying puzzle!
I was able to solve it though it took me longer to do-- (I didn't get the theme until very late.)
Forgave myself for being so blind because I'm only starting to do the crossword again after many years and don't have much experience with such creative structures!
Will think more out of the box next time I hope!!

Very late to the party today. A beautiful construction, which was ruined by overly easy clues. Or, as Norma Dolores Egstrom said, "Then let's keep dancing.": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DLeSyb_ZEa8&list=RDDLeSyb_ZEa8&start_radio=1 On the other hand, I had very little time for the puzzle either last night or today, so there's that.
Loved the puzzle hated the niche crossing names.
Fun puzzle with a clever theme!

I resolved at the start of this year to solve every crossword this year (with the help of my mom and the wordplay blog) and I am proud to say this is the first Sunday Theme I was able to uncover on my own. The revealer was super helpful and not hard to uncover early in the solve.

All the themed entries were very clever and I was a huge fan of SMITHEREENS. Just want to share this for my own crossword record as it really made me feel like I am actually improving.
This was clever and so much fun. I love a classic, well-done theme paired with good fill. This was so that!

@Barry Ancona

Before I had a subscription (that is, before my wife wanted NYT recipes) I had to rely on the the few freebies the NYT doled out.

I was afraid of Thursday through Saturday, but I tried a Thursday that had this kind of gimmick.  

I was verklempt.  Totally verklempt.  I verklempted, then I verklempted some more.

Barry Ancona,

“the execution here”

Yes, we were hanging on every word, by the end.

Barry Ancona
As newcomer, I definitely did not get a thrill.
@Bill in Yokohama me too. Downhill means you can coast the rest of the way. Never knew the “getting worse” meaning

@Bill in Yokohama
It has at least 2 meanings. 
The one you mentioned is like "we can just coast now, because the hard work is done"

A second one is "you've reached peak condition, so it can only get worse from now on". Often said of someone in their twenties (or thirties, or fourties) by someone 10 years older.

@Bill in Yokohama

I’ve heard it both ways, but typically I I use it to mean things are getting worse

@Bill in Yokohama

Oh, yeah... Just like the 'golden years'. They're fun (NOT).
Don't rush to the summit and go "over the hill".
:)

@Bill in Yokohama

It depends on the context. “Once I figured out that clue, it was all downhill from there” =easier. But I mostly see it used as a negative: “The comments section went downhill after they changed the format” or “Everything’s been going downhill since that carrot took office”. Because while traveling a downward slope may be easier, it can also mean you’ve already peaked, and unless you change paths, you’re headed toward the bottom.
@Bill in Yokohama I agree. Going "down hill" is always easier. I have never heard of downhill meaning "after the peak".

@Lewis

In my haste to get my Fiend review up and move on to cooking dinner, I missed that the drop-offs are all from HERE. Thanks for pointing that out. (My apologies to Caitlin Lovinger, who probably mentioned this in her column (which I've not yet read).)

Eric,
She does, at the very end of Today's Theme.

@DQ

So you had a "m-i-t-s-a-k-e" that had to be RESPELLED?

@Casey Klep

Some days are like that, when it all seems like a foreign language. Don't let it get you down.

In any case, thank you for sharing your experience with such grace, without chewing out the constructors or editors. 

Hang in there; tomorrow's another (fresh new) day. ;-)

@Casey Klep

Yeah, that really feels awful.  Complete whiff.  Nothing, and I mean No Thing comes to mind, clue after clue.

I am certainly no stranger to that feeling.

I'd love to hear an explanation for it.  Probably a combination of things all working on the same side of the Gaussian curve.

@Casey Klep
Foggy? Nothing works? Close it, put it down. Make a cuppa something. Watch a half hour of TV, or read for a bit. 

Go back to the puzzle and the answers might be easier.  When I started, I couldn't even get helios.  Duh! 

Quibble: shouldn't Moon be capitalized in the clue?

@Cat Lady Margaret
My first guess was BADDREAM
@Cat Lady Margaret count me in team leg cramp
@Kevin it’s Sunday and in the NYT Xword world, Sunday comes just after Thursday for puzzles with varying entry methods.

@Kevin

It went downhill.

@Andrzej
As I said I did add HERE at the end of the themers which decreased the difficulty a bit—but the theme was so clever and appropriate I didn’t mind, and though it did give me a leg up it didn’t make any of the themers gimmes for me; and the rest of the puzzle was clued at an appropriate level (probably a Wednesday level, which is definitely on the easy side for me but what I expect for a Sunday). I find when I am engaged with a clever theme, interesting fill, and generally original clues I don’t  get as hung up on the difficulty.

Hm. To me the revealer was such a huge spoiler I just can't get over it. It was like being handed the answer key. I'm glad you had a better time with the grid than I did.

I genuinely felt a bit disappointed to realize it was actually just WEED TEA. So uncreative! C'mon, cool young people, do better.

commentBody:
@Matt

Politics aside, he was a silver-nibbed master of alliteration.

@Erin

Google "eeo vs eoe"
@Erin EOE I believe that EOE and EEO may be used interchangeably, although I think that EOE is the official designation now.

@Erin

A hyphen connects words that serve as adjectives before a noun, , so I would say this clue is correct. 

One that I encounter in my work all the time as a person who works in donor stewardship is this: 

-Thank you so much for your generous gift.  

-I am going to send a thank-you card for their generous gift.

It's not unusual for people to get it wrong, but hyphens, like emus, work in mysterious ways apparently.

@Erin

I always knew it to be Equal Opportunity Employer – until five years ago, when I started doing the NYT xwords and encountered Equal Employment Opportunity. 

I still always put in EOE and have to change it to EEO. 
Today was the first time EOE was right!

@sotto voce

Samesies!!

userLocation: Spring Hill, just south of Armageddon
commentBody:
@Erin

What @HeathieJ said.

The exception being when one of the words is an adverb ending in "-ly."

It's "the happily married couple" and NOT "the happily-married couple," for example.

Adverbs without the -ly ending do get the hypen.

Like "well-earned rest."

@HeathieJ

:-) (hi, lovely lady!)

@Matt

Yes, thank you for adding that!!
@Jon Onstot whereas if you are an aging farmer named McDonald, it is EIEIO….

@HeathieJ

This is a rule that's ignored often when the two words making up the modifier are a set phrase.  

Most people would write "ice cream sandwich," not "ice-cream sandwich."

I was once a high school teacher.  You wouldn't likely see it written as "high-school teacher," although some publications' stylebooks insist upon it (I'm looking at you, New Yorker).

The logic is that a "high school teacher" might be one who works in a high school on a mountain, not to be confused with a "high schoolteacher," who might be on drugs.  

In the clue under discussion, though, the words "fair hiring" doesn't have the same coherence as "ice cream" or "high school," though.

@Matt

But why make the distinction?

userLocation: Spring Hill, just south of Armageddon
commentBody:
@Steve L

No idea.

The evolution and expression of grammatic rules in language is similar to genetic expression in speciation, if you ask me.

Similar mysteries, randomness, changeabilities, inscrutabilities.

Or have I misunderstood your question?

@Matt

It was rhetorical. I’d say it’s a style issue, not a grammatical one.

Cherry,

I said earlier, and will reiterate, that it doesn't seem "in the language" to me, but as I said then, I'm sure you could find some instances out there.

@Alexia Either is acceptable. It depends on whether you mean "this is the edition belonging to teachers" or "this edition includes additional material." Illustrated edition, annotated edition, teacher edition, etc.

Suzanne,
The clue clearly describes the latter, and teachers and publishers are correctly noting that the S version is almost always the case. The version in the puzzle does exist somewhere though, so while it may belong is the same category as DEAGED, there is no reason to DROP it HERE.

Teacher’s edition. Belongs to the teacher. 

Teacher’ editions. Belongs to the teachers. 

Teachers’ edition.  Made for teachers.

It's raining sideways, with chilly wind, but the farmers are so desperate in this ongoing drought that I stifle any protestation about the gloom.  Yesterday was pretty, and I got around to all the folks for whom I had Springerle cookies, so the fun of it will provide enough buoyancy to get past my grumbles.  hah.

@Steve,

@Steve the nba star? :-)

@Dave Munger

I got IS THAT ALL THERE first and since the IS was at the beginning, it totally yeeped me.

@Joe Since moving to Sacramento, the team has been known simply as the Athletics, without a preceding city name. Consequently, they appear as ATH on scoreboards. This has become a point of contention for Sacramentans, who are miffed that the organization refuses to lean into its new home, even if the stay is only temporary.

@Joe
Alas, poor Oakland. It used to be a nice place to live, but everybody's moving out. And the baseball team has been simply "The A's" for as long as I can remember.

@Marcus

They do not appear as ATH on scoreboards. It's either OAK or now, LAS. Now team is referred to by a theee letter acronym od the mascot. City and state names are used. Like LAL and LAC.  Neither is LAK or CLI.

I’ve never seen LAS. Is that something that is just done locally? I instantly got ATH on 16D based on my recollection of watching 2025 MLB games, and reconfirmed just now looking up game highlights on YouTube. It’s all ATH. Example: https://youtu.be/XhW6OBU4vds

@Joe That’s simply incorrect. Since 2025, the team has played in Sacramento under official MLB guidelines that mandate they be listed as ATH on all scoreboards and schedules. They are no longer "OAK," and because they aren't in Nevada yet, they have never been "LAS." You can verify this on any 2025 box score. They are the only team in the league currently using a mascot-based acronym instead of a city code.

@Joe

What Marcus said.

@Marcus As an As fan and a former Sacramentan, I don't know about that. The local AAA team (River Cats) has been affiliated with the SF Giants, not Oakland, for many years. The AAA fans don't all like this big team coming into their lovely little stadium in West Sacramento. And the permanent location of the As will be out of state, in Las Vegas (fill in your own insults here).

Kick-ss crossword constructor and cures cancer. Gotta be a special Nobel prize for that.

Stay strong!

@Mean Old Lady my kids are mid 30's and I fear they're aging out of the newest linguistic updates... and my grandbaby is 9 months so can't help me. But fortunately I hear a lot in my mutual aid group from the early 20's crowd!

I don't like _all_ the slang. "Drip", for example, gives me an unpleasant mental image at odds with the new meaning. There's something I love about YEET. Not sure why but it sounds almost Shakespearean.

MOL,
NOE Valley, NOB Hill? Did your time in NoCal not include any time in San Francisco?
@Barry Ancona, I've spent a fair amount of time in San Francisco but wasn't familiar with that neighborhood. 🤷🏼‍♀️

Susan,
I assume the "fair amount of time" was visiting, not living in, San Francisco. NOE Valley isn't a major tourist spot.

I figured since there is a Nob Hill, it's probably right next to the Valley.
@Sue I live in San Francisco and loved Noe - yet it’s not like SoHo / Williamsburg / Lincoln Park / the Pearl / Bourbon Street … I don’t think it’s an easy one for most people.

(1) All but the newest Crosslandia residents should know it:
Sun Nov 23, 2025	
53A	
San Francisco's ___ Valley 	
Trenton Charlson

(2) What other letters would make sense in the crosses?

@Barry Ancona.   My husband and I spent one month a year for 15 years at the Huntington, his business involved, and many incidental trips for pleasure thereafter, but no one ever used “Noe Valley” in conversation with me.  Walking the city was my main occupation, I had friends to visit.  This has been in the crossward before, and I looked it up on Google earth, so did know where it was.  But, yes, it is possible to spend time there without hearing or seeing this word.

Claire,
I'm not surprised that your walks from the Huntington did not take you to Noe Valley. One of my great-great aunts spent the last years of her life living in the Mark Hopkins. I'm sure she didn't walk to Noe Valley either.
Barry, none did for me 🤣

Andrzej,
No *other* letters worked for you,

@Barry Ancona
In fact, I spent quite a lot of time in The City despite living an hour (if lucky) away (in Palo Alto, Sunnyvale)....especially we visited spots on "Pill Hill" where our daughter was hospitalized and had surgery, plus dozens of trips to get bracing, etc.  My technique was to take her to one of the museums down the hill for an hour and then go back to the orthotics lab where we could all see where the 'hot spots' were.  Spared me another long two-way drive . Then there was the peds ophthalmologist who was in San Mateo.  And her PT and her school were in Cupertino.  Gosh, I don't understand how I could have missed all the touristy places like Noe Valley...which  I've still never heard of.

@Lynn

A welcome surprise from the moderators for sure. The people at the NYT have more sense than the bots.
@Grumpy On a similar note, since “mucho” is Spanish, shouldn’t the answer (lotsa) also be in Spanish?

When abbreviations like ET AL and "etc" are used in print more frequently than what they abbreviate, they become words of their own in dictionaries, and do not need an "abbr. signal" in a crossword clue (although they may get one early in the week). ET AL is now a word in English from Latin. [Latin list ender] is a perfectly cromulent crossword clue.

[Mucho] is also English slang, and thus a fine clue for LOTSA.
Foreign language answers require a clue signal; not all "foreign" words in a clue lead to a foreign language answer.

@Barry Ancona
Thank goodness we can all rest easy, now that the ultimate authority has made his proclamation. No more disagreement with the NYT puzzle cluing decisions needed (or allowed).

@Barry Ancona
No. If the clue had been simply "List ender", you might have a point. But it said "Latin list ender". Whether or not ET AL is in the English language is irrelevant, because the clue calls for an answer in Latin.
@Andrew Thanks, I had LOTTA till now.  And since I don't play bridge I figured EAST T was something.

@Darren

Not sure what you think are bad clues, but the theme helped me solve the puzzle.

Darren,
Many people reported understanding the theme just from title, and only realizing what the revealer actually revealed only after solving the crossword. And many people enjoy trying to guess the revealer from the theme. This is supposed to be a puzzle.
@Barry Ancona snark is present!
@Rich in Atlanta -- According to XwordInfo, that is the most famous NYT crossword.  It was one of the first Schroedinger puzzles (that term coined by constructor Joon Pahk)

Glad I found it.

@Ed Blond
A FLASH -- An instant, a very short moment in time.

@michael mccann

I'm surprised xwstats has it as "Average" since a hack like me thought it was easy. I guess the peanut gallery is willing to forgive the easiness in exchange for an elegant construction. I've been doing Sunday puzzles from several years ago lately, and it's certainly MUCH easier than those.

@Elbridge Gerry
now i feel sad

Read more than the first word on xwstats:

Median Solver15% faster
⚡77% of users solved faster than their Sunday average.
40% solved much faster (>20%) than their Sunday average.

@Barry Ancona
you're not helping
https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/nabob

@CrispinG

You must be too young to remember Agnew's "[n]attering nabobs of negativism", a phrase crafted by the great William Safire.

@William Kash
I might also be too young, because after the word “remember” not a word of that makes any sense to me!
@CrispinG a fun inclusion in a mystical wish-granter's lexicon, so I realized 30 years later.

@Convoid-04

Half my personal bests are wrong anyway because I solved them off Wifi then later when I got back onto Wifi, the solve time was reflected based on what the timer read when Wifi dropped.  So my Wednesday PB is like 2 minutes.  I wish they had a way to remove false records and get your real one back.

userLocation: Spring training again. Ahh, at last! ⚾️

commentBody:
@Niall

I thought the DDE answer was IKE because he's much more commonly referred to by his nickname than his initials.

@Niall
I really like your comment. Feel as though I've stepped across the pond and am looking back.

I had sOHO at first as well, even though where I live is also known as NOHO, though not the one referred to in the puzzle. We like to elevate ourselves.

I think DDE is not only continent-specific, but age-specific. I remember as a child my dad loading us all into the family station wagon when we lived in Augusta and driving us to Daniel Field to watch for Ike's private plane to land for the Master's Tournament. You could get up close and watch plane after plane come in over your head. What a thrill.

@SBK
True on the themes, they mostly don’t make much impact either way.

@Chris

In this instance, the clue referring to John F. Kennedy as his initials, was a hint the answer would also be initials.

@Niall
As avid bridge players, my wife and I consider positions as post bid, not seats at the table. Thusly, EASTS was a bit of... uhh, yeah, sure... reactions.

@Bill
TIL Miss Peggy Lee's original name. Thanks!
